channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Mild US Inflation Is Backdrop for Fed’s Powell on the Hill
item.description: US inflation probably inched higher in May, offering scant evidence of extensive tariff-related repercussions that the Federal Reserve expects to become more apparent later in the year.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 18, 2025. Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged and continued to pencil in two rate cuts in 2025, saying uncertainty over the economic outlook was still high but had diminished.

item.title: Chinese Biotech Showcases Challenger to Eli Lilly’s Obesity Drug
item.description: An obesity drug from China helped patients lose a lot of weight in a late-stage clinical trial, making it a prospective new challenger to blockbusters from Novo Nordisk A/S and Eli Lilly & Co.
item.dc:creator: Amber Tong

media:content.media:description: Injection pen parts on the Wegovy line at the Novo Nordisk A/S production facilities in Hillerod, Denmark, on Friday, March 8, 2024. Novo is Europe's most valuable company and little in Denmark can escape the drugmaker's gravitational pull. Photographer: Carsten Snejbjerg/Bloomberg

item.title: Commercial Real Estate Distress Is Spreading: Credit Weekly
item.description: The pain in US commercial real estate credit continues to bubble to the surface after a surge in borrowing costs and the rise of work from home left lenders vulnerable to losses.
item.dc:creator: Neil Callanan

media:content.media:description: An empty office space in a building in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, Dec. 5, 2023. San Francisco's office vacancy rate reached a record 34% in the third quarter, according to the real estate brokerage CBRE Group.

item.title: Congo Extends Cobalt Export Ban by Three Months to Curb Supplies
item.description: The Democratic Republic of Congo extended a temporary ban on cobalt exports for an additional three months, according to a statement from a regulatory agency, prolonging its efforts to rein in a glut on the international market.
item.dc:creator: William Clowes

media:content.media:description: Sacks of cobalt powder on a truck for export at the Etoile mine, operated by Chemaf Sarl, in Katanga province near Lubumbashi, the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Wednesday, Dec. 22, 2021. Along a 250-mile highway which cuts through central Africa, thousands of flatbed trucks haul sheets of copper and sacks of cobalt hydroxide, essential for electric cars and other 21st century technologies for which drivers must pay steep tolls, as much as $900 for a round trip. Photographer: Lucien Kahozi/Bloomberg

item.title: Can Saudi Arabia’s Aramco Fuel a New Era?
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s Aramco has been synonymous with oil, but its next generation extends far beyond petrochemicals. The company is evolving into a tech-driven energy giant, investing heavily in AI, renewables, and low-carbon initiatives like hydrogen and carbon capture. Despite geopolitical tensions, Aramco remains the backbone of Saudi government revenue. We travel to Dhahran to get a first-hand look at the parallel stories of the Kingdom and Aramco. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Airlines Locked Out of Iran Air Space Move to Afghanistan Route
item.description: After the air space across large swaths of the Middle East turned into a no-fly zone, the skies over Afghanistan have become increasingly crowded as airlines seek alternative flight paths to connect Asia with Europe and the US.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: This aerial view shows Kokcha river flowing across the Fayzabad city in Badakhshan province on February 27, 2024. (Photo by Wakil KOHSAR / AFP) (Photo by WAKIL KOHSAR/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: WAKIL KOHSAR/AFP

item.title: Summers on the Fed, Middle East and NYC Mayoral Primary
item.description: Fed Chair Powell says uncertainty around tariffs justifies holding interest rates steady for now. Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers agrees but warns that rising inflation and unemployment make the Fed’s job harder. He also highlights the potential economic fallout from U.S.-Iran tensions. Summers criticizes New York mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani’s platform as “profoundly dangerous” for not only the city, but also for the country. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stock Market’s Path Depends on Fed’s View of What We Don’t Know
item.description: For investors and traders trying to game out where the US economy, the stock market or interest rates are headed in the second half of 2025, good luck. There’s simply too much uncertainty to be sure of anything right now.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey, Jess Menton

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of American Stock Exchange (AMEX) at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Friday, June 20, 2025. US stocks rose on Friday as investors returned from the Juneteenth holiday break to evaluate recent comments from a top Federal Reserve official as well as the latest developments in the conflict between Israel and Iran.

item.title: SNB Cut to Negative Would Be Much Bigger Step Than ‘Normal’ Reduction, Schlegel Says
item.description: Swiss National Bank President Martin Schlegel said cutting interest rates below zero is a more significant move than a reduction above that level, suggesting the central bank may be hesitant to take such a step.
item.dc:creator: Levin Stamm

media:content.media:description: Martin Schlegel, president of the Swiss National Bank (SNB), during the bank's rate announcement news conference in Zurich, Switzerland, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. The Swiss National Bank cut its interest rate to zero, seeking to deter investors from pushing up the franc after the currency’s strength caused consumer prices to drop for the first time in four years.

item.title: Russia’s Top Oil Executive Says OPEC+ Was Astute to Boost Output
item.description: Steps taken by the OPEC+ group to boost oil supplies have proved astute, given developments in the Middle East conflict, according to Rosneft PJSC Chief Executive Officer Igor Sechin.
item.dc:creator: James Herron

media:content.media:description: Oil storage tanks stand at the RN-Tuapsinsky refinery, operated by Rosneft Oil Co., at night in Tuapse, Russia, on Sunday, March 22, 2020. Major oil currencies have fallen much more this month following the plunge in Brent crude prices to less than $30 a barrel, with Russia’s ruble down by 15%. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: Giuseppe Paleologo on Quant Investing at Multi-Strat Hedge Funds
item.description: How do you actually make money?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Stock market information at the Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. Five days after President Donald Trump’s America-versus-the-world trade war threw stock and bond markets around the world into disarray, he backpedaled and, in the process, pulled the financial system back from the brink.

item.title: Odd Lots: Quant Investing at Multi-Strat Hedge Funds (Podcast)
item.description: Quantitative investing is one of those terms that you hear all the time, but there’s various explanations of what it actually means, or how quants actually make money. And of course, the term means different things in different contexts. In this live episode, recorded at the Bloomberg Equity Intelligence Summit on June 12, we speak again with Giuseppe Paleologo, the head of quantitative research at Balyasny Asset Management. We talk about his role, what quant investing actually is, and what the
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Turkey Boosts Reserve Rules on Some Deposits to Support Lira
item.description: Turkey raised the amount of cash lenders must park with the central bank against some deposits, as part of measures to support the lira after it became the worst-performer in the Europe, Middle East and Africa region.
item.dc:creator: Asli Kandemir

media:content.media:description: The waterfront in the Eminonu district of Istanbul, Turkey, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. Turkish markets buckled on Wednesday after the detention of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s most prominent rival, Ekrem Imamoglu, stoked concern that political upheaval risks undermining recent investor-friendly economic policies.

item.title: India to See Limited Inflation Fallout From Oil, Government Adviser Says
item.description: India’s top government adviser said rising oil prices are likely to have a limited impact on inflation for now and Asia’s third-largest economy remains in a relatively favorable position to weather global risks.
item.dc:creator: Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: A motorcyclist rides past an oil pipeline near an oil refinery in Mumbai. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Summers on the Fed, Aramco Evolution, Future of AI, Themed Entertainment Industry | Wall Street Week
item.description: This week, Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers on the recent Fed decision and the economic implications of uncertainty in the Middle East. And, how is Saudi giant Aramco diversifying in a tech-driven world? Plus, an interview with Robinhood’s Vlad Tenev on artificial intelligence solutions for nuanced needs. Later, Netflix is entering the themed entertainment business with Netflix House, further intensifying its competition with traditional media players. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P 500 Trading Volume Spikes at Wall Street Close | The Close 6/20/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Anthony Saglimbene, Ameriprise Financial, Chris O’Cull, Stifel Financial, Jacob DeWitte, Oklo, Ray Takeyh, Council on Foreign Relations, Cole Smead, Smead Capital Management, Que Nguyen, Research Affiliates, Sonali Theisen, Bank of America, Joe Mathieu, Bloomberg News, Kim Wallace, 22V Research, Ice Cube, Big3, Jennifer Openshaw, Girls With Impact. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Shock-Proof Oil Stocks to Weather the Geopolitical Storm
item.description: Cole Smead, Smead Capital Management, CEO & Portfolio Manager speaks with Romaine Bostick and Scarlet Fu about navigating the volatile oil market. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Obstructions Remain in Potential US-Iran Talks: Expert
item.description: Ray Takeyh, Senior Fellow at The Council on Foreign Relations speaks with Romaine Bostick and Scarlet Fu about the Israel and Iran conflict and the role the US will play. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oklo CEO on What's Driven the Stock Up +500% in a Year
item.description: Jacob DeWitte, Oklo CEO & Co-Founder speaks with Romaine Bostick and Scarlet Fu about the success of Oklo this past year and what the future holds. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ardian's Mark Benedetti on Democratizing PE (Correct)
item.description: Ardian Executive President Mark Benedetti discuses the democratization of private equity on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Corrects spelling of guest's name in headline) (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Musk’s xAI Lures Investors to Sweetened $5 Billion Debt Deal
item.description: Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence startup xAI Corp. lured enough investors to its $5 billion debt deal by offering sweeter pricing on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Gowri Gurumurthy, Rachel Graf

item.title: How Ice Cube's Big3 Is Changing the Game
item.description: Music Legend, Actor and Producer Ice Cube discusses how Big3, the 3-on-3 basketball league he founded, is changing the game with Romaine Bostick on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ‘Abolishing FEMA’ Memo Outlines Ways for Trump to Scrap Agency
item.description:
A memo titled "Abolishing FEMA" outlines ways for Trump to scrap the agency.
Zahra Hirji explains how the administration aims to create a re-branded, radically smaller disaster response organization. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: CarMax Earnings Show Rise in Used Car Demand | Bloomberg Markets 6/20/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests; Bloomberg's Nir Kaissar, David Welch, Michelle Cortez, and Rachel Phua. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Refining Capacity Declines Amid Uncertain Fuel Demand Outlook
item.description: US refiners’ operating capacity edged lower in 2024 as an uncertain outlook for gasoline and diesel prompted fuelmakers to pull back after a period of expansion.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Risser

item.title: S&P 500 Trading Volume Spikes at Wall Street Close: Markets Wrap
item.description: A jittery week ended with losses in stocks as investors weighed geopolitical and trade developments, chipmakers sank while a $6.5 trillion options expiration spurred a surge in volume. Short-dated yields fell as Federal Reserve’s Christopher Waller said rates could drop as early as July.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Hedge Funds Rush Into Oil Long Bets as Mideast Conflict Grows
item.description: Hedge funds boosted their bullish position in Brent crude by the most since early October as Israel’s strikes against Iran’s nuclear program imperiled a region that produces around a third of the world’s oil.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis

item.title: Trump Says Iran Wants to Speak With US, Not Europe
item.description: President Donald Trump says two weeks is the maximum amount of time he will allow to pursue diplomacy with Iran while speaking with reporters. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Equities Finish Choppy Session Lower | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Wall Street’s First-Half Whiplash Rewards All-Weather Portfolios
item.description: Somehow, for all its drama — tariffs, fiscal brinkmanship, inflation fears, and geopolitical flare-ups — the first half of 2025 may be remembered by diversified investors for something else entirely: the strongest stretch of synchronized market gains in years.
item.dc:creator: Denitsa Tsekova, Emily Graffeo

media:content.media:description: Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, on June 20.
